title: European System for Cardiac Operative Risk Evaluation (EuroSCORE) II
description: Predicts risk of in-hospital mortality after major cardiac surgery using logistic regression model with 18 validated variables.

parameters.name: chronic_pulmonary_dysfunction
parameters.description: Chronic pulmonary dysfunction requiring bronchodilators or steroids

parameters.name: mobility_dysfunction
parameters.description: Neurological or musculoskeletal dysfunction severely affecting mobility

parameters.name: critical_preoperative_state
parameters.description: Critical preoperative state (mechanical ventilation, inotropes, IABP, or renal failure)

parameters.name: extracardiac_arteriopathy
parameters.description: Extracardiac arteriopathy (claudication, carotid occlusion, or stroke)

parameters.name: previous_cardiac_surgery
parameters.description: Previous cardiac surgery opening the pericardium

result.name: mortality_risk
result.description: Predicted in-hospital mortality risk percentage and risk stratification

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of in-hospital mortality. Standard perioperative care and monitoring recommended.
Medium risk of in-hospital mortality. Enhanced perioperative monitoring and care planning recommended.
High risk of in-hospital mortality. Intensive perioperative care, multidisciplinary team approach, and careful risk-benefit assessment recommended.
Very high risk of in-hospital mortality. Consider alternative treatments, intensive perioperative support, and detailed discussion with patient and family regarding risks and benefits.

references: Nashef SA, Roques F, Sharples LD, Nilsson J, Smith C, Goldstone AR, Lockowandt U. EuroSCORE II. Eur J Cardiothorac Surg. 2012 Apr;41(4):734-44; discussion 744-5. doi: 10.1093/ejcts/ezs043.
Roques F, Michel P, Goldstone AR, Nashef SA. The logistic EuroSCORE. Eur Heart J. 2003 May;24(9):881-2. doi: 10.1016/s0195-668x(02)00799-6.

Nashef SA, Roques F, Michel P, Gauducheau E, Lemeshow S, Salamon R. European system for cardiac operative risk evaluation (EuroSCORE). Eur J Cardiothorac Surg. 1999 Jul;16(1):9-13. doi: 10.1016/s1010-7940(99)00134-7.

Grant SW, Hickey GL, Dimarakis I, Trivedi U, Bryan A, Treasure T, Cooper G, Pagano D, McCollum C, Bridgewater B. How does EuroSCORE II perform in UK cardiac surgery; an analysis of 23 740 patients from the Society for Cardiothoracic Surgery in Great Britain and Ireland National Database. Heart. 2012 Dec;98(21):1568-72. doi: 10.1136/heartjnl-2012-302483.
formula: EuroSCORE II uses logistic regression: Predicted mortality (%) = 100 × e^y / (1 + e^y), where y = -5.324537 + Σ(coefficient × variable)
notes: Based on 22,381 patients undergoing cardiac surgery in 154 hospitals across 43 countries
Uses logistic regression model with constant β0 = -5.324537
Well calibrated with area under ROC curve of 0.8095
Significant improvement over original EuroSCORE in contemporary practice
Reduces overestimation of mortality risk by approximately 50%
Age coefficient increases by 1 point per year after age 60
Creatinine clearance is better predictor than absolute serum creatinine
Includes insulin-dependent diabetes as separate risk factor
Surgery urgency and complexity are key procedural factors
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
Validated for in-hospital mortality, not long-term outcomes
May need local calibration in specific populations
Regular updates recommended as surgical practices evolve
Not applicable to transcatheter procedures or minimally invasive surgery
